key_findings: Explainable AI methods (SHAP and LIME) can effectively identify tokens that make AI-generated text detectable, enabling targeted modifications to reduce detectability through four proposed token replacement strategies.

Ensemble classifier combining bert-base-multilingual-uncased, distilbert-base-multilingual-cased, and xlm-roberta-base with concatenated representations and L2 regularization maintains robust detection performance across multiple languages and domains.

Token replacement approaches can significantly diminish single classifier detection capabilities, but ensemble approaches prove more resilient to such adversarial modifications, demonstrating the arms race between generation and detection.

Multi-model ensemble approach mitigates overfitting risks by freezing pre-trained weights and leveraging complementary features from different transformer architectures, with hyperparameter optimization focused on F1 scores.

The research demonstrates practical implications for both AI text detection systems and potential misuse scenarios, highlighting the need for robust multi-model detection approaches in real-world applications.
limitations: Token replacement strategies may degrade text quality while attempting to reduce detectability
Ensemble approach requires significantly more computational resources than single model detection
future_work: Development of more sophisticated token replacement strategies that maintain text quality while reducing detectability

resource_requirements.compute_requirements: Multiple transformer models (BERT variants, DistilBERT, XLM-RoBERTa)
resource_requirements.data_requirements: AuTexTification dataset for training and evaluation

problem_addressed: Reducing detectability of AI-generated text while developing robust detection methods to counter such evasion techniques
real_world_applications: AI content detection systems for academic integrity
